As the media historian Benjamin Peters suggests, when neoliberal proponents of the internet imagine the transformation of the nation into a network, what they see is not so much that the body of the nation gains a brain in the form of the network, than that it becomes one. In its entirety, with the bodies that make up the nation, in turn, becoming neurons within the network. In other words, the brain here is not a tentacular omega sitting at the centre of a vast nervous system belonging to a single organism, but an entirely disembodied network of neurons. Firing at each other without taking direction from a centre. A brain without a body. This disappearance of the body politic effectively transforms the nation into a kind of marketplace of individuals, imagined less as bodies engaged in physical labour, than as purely cognitive entities, free to enter into peer-to-peer relations with each other. Like in a film where Scarlett Johansson plays some artificial or artificially enhanced entity, the network here has become invisible, because it is everywhere. Yet, just as how we don't think about the so-called invisible hand of the market until a financial crisis hits. The ongoing disruptions caused by machine learning, whether it be upon democratic politics, policing, personal privacy, or economic security, have forced a collective reckoning with the planetary scale architecture of control that has been built upon the internet. And just like how a financial crisis is typically followed by the attribution of blame to certain bodies, The numerous scandals arising from ever new forms of technology have made us rethink the assumption of a completely disembodied network. We have already seen how in addressing the problem of bias in AI, we seem to instinctively turn to the dataset in hope of tracing the problem to a human body, such as the data researcher responsible for selecting the images to go into the training data set, Who might or might not be someone who looks like this. Alternatively, the bias could also come from the one who labels the data. Who is likely to be not a computer professional, but one of the millions of so-called crowd workers to whom such a task is usually outsourced. As part of a shadow economy that performs all kinds of laborious micro-tasks that keep the digital economy running, from labelling training data to checking content flagged for moderation, Crowd workers are typically hired on demand and can work from any place in the world with an internet connection. Should they coalesce into any expression of collectivity, it is less likely to take the form of a literal crowd. Than to resemble something like this. Indeed, on the other end of the network, as more and more scrutiny is being directed to so-called big tech companies, we have also been seeing the emergence of the CEO as public showman, as the leaders of these companies use the force of their personality. To reassure the public after each scandal that the company's financial interests do not take precedence over public safety. In a curious reversal of the distributed logic of the neural network, such companies are becoming increasingly identified with their leaders, who, in turn, appear within the public imagination as the personification of the body politic of today's data capitalism. As data and computing power become concentrated within a small number of large multinationals, the flows of information within today's global economy are looking less like neurons firing away in a disembodied brain, and more like drones moving in circles within prescribed territories, where they are subjected to the master algorithm of the data capitalist. With public distrust growing by the day, calls coming from different sections of society to regulate or even ban some of these platforms have only become louder. However, as AI continues to permeate all aspects of our lives, I wonder if it's enough to merely regulate or restrict how individuals, companies, or governmental organizations access and use publicly available data. Certainly, diversifying datasets and breaking up tech monopolies will produce redistributive effects. Yet in doing all these, we would still, at best, only be tackling the nodes within the network, and not addressing the network itself. And the ways in which the network has already become. A part of us. The question, in other words, is not how to improve and update the network, but how to rethink the very grounds upon which we turn to the network. To begin with. I'm talking about the grounds of intelligence itself. As many neuroscientists have argued, to say that deep learning mirrors how the human brain learns misrepresents both how machines learn and how the brain actually works. While they may very well come a day when the entire structure of the brain can be replicated in machine form, The claim that deep learning models learn just as humans do, reduces the numerous faculties of the brain to a single function that such models appear especially adept at, namely, pattern recognition. Moreover, as seen from the surreal and unexpected images that deep learning can conjure, machines are also able to perceive patterns that elude human perception. This ability is almost entirely the result of a distinctly inhuman vision that sees the world as composed of probabilistic distributions of noise. Consequently, while such models have proven to be extremely competent at rendering complex textures, they struggle with basic tasks, like depicting the right number of fingers on the human hand. Some technologists believe that problems of such nature will be resolved once such models are able to directly access the three-dimensional world. For it would give them the one ability that they currently sorely lack to fully simulate the world, as we know it, the ability to distinguish figure from ground. But what if the relationship between figure and ground is not a technical, but a political question? After all, what lies between the figure and its ground is not just three-dimensional space, but a relation of causality. That is, it is the ground that gives rise to the figure. That these models are unable to distinguish figure from ground might thus suggest a difficulty in understanding not space, but time. Specifically, historical time. And to grasp the political implications of this lack, we only need to remember the long and troubled history of intelligence itself, which is nothing less than the history of the forgetting of history. As we have seen, this is a history inextricable from the history of colonialism and its post-colonial afterlives. As the history of the evacuation of figures from their grounds of existence, it encompasses the uprooting of entire communities from their existing ways of life, to be resettled into networks, where they become data points, producing data to be collected, aggregated and analysed by the so-called intelligentsia of society. Whether it is in the name of improvement or development, What forms the ideological basis of this extraction of figure from ground is the idea that problem solving is essentially a question of space, and that any problem can be solved through finding the right form of organisation. How a problem originated, thus, became irrelevant to the task of solving it. In fact, for the architect of a nation newly freed from the yoke of colonialism, there was the risk that dwelling too much on the past would weigh the nation down, holding it back from discovering new ways to redesign the present. Today, thanks to machine learning, intelligence is no longer the sole property of the colonial administrator or state planner, but that of the entire nation. Thanks to the transformation of the nation into a network, the entire population can now become smart. Here, what distinguishes this general intelligence is that it actually sees history as a valuable resource and seeks to learn from it, but only without having to spend the time to understand it. History, after all, produces data. But it also produces much more than data. So much more that it makes any attempt at learning from history a necessarily arduous process, especially if one had to actually remember what happened. If only there was a way to learn from history without having to remember it. What's so intelligent about the deep learning network, then, is that it allows us to do just that. And it does so not by disappearing history into the void, but by turning it into noise, which then becomes the ground for all kinds of figures to emerge through the activation of numerous feedback loops. Learning here thus happens not through any kind of immersion into deep historical time, but through fragments of historical data randomly making their way through the deep architecture of the neural network, in a sign of the literal disposability of history within this process. These models, upon completing their training, hold no memory of the original data, which is discarded after the training process. In the same way that the brain imagined by cybernetizens does not store exact representations of the world, but only the patterns of neurons firing in response to external stimuli, all that is retained by the model is the memory of their time processing the data, encoded in mathematical form. This also means that when we talk about creating the future, with AI. What we need to understand is that what's produced by AI in its current form is not really the future per se, in all its indeterminacy, but merely an original reorganization of an abstracted version of the past. Within this schema, history and disappearing into noise also refigures the future as a vast field of ever-emerging patterns, or seeming to offer endless possibilities. This spatialization of the future, in fact, reduces its radical openness to an always reconfigurable present. After all, if the present is the interval where we re-examine history in order to imagine the future, the collapse of both history and the future onto the neural network then renders this task impossible. Consequently, the process of learning from history no longer involves judging the events of history according to any kind of absolute principle. Such as justice, fairness, or equality, But is instead determined by the rules of probability, wherein the goal is not to find the best outcome for a given problem, but the optimal one, that is, the best possible outcome, given a predefined set of constraints. Yet, to speak of the best possible outcome, one must first be able to establish all possible outcomes, which can only be logically obtained by reducing the future. To some version of what we already know. Here, the risk is not simply that a model constrained by a so-called bias dataset will end up repeating the mistakes of history as inscribed within the data. Rather, what's arguably more dangerous is that a diversified dataset deemed to have overcome the problem of bias becomes the basis for allowing AI to find the best possible solution to a problem that we humans, with all our biases, have not been able to solve. As if the parameters that mark out what's possible to begin with. Are not already ideologically drawn. In fact, we are already seeing this happening, with the many proposals calling for the use of AI to fix the so-called crisis of democracy, that reflects neither on the origins of the crisis, nor on the possibility that the entire political structure needs to be rethought. Against the ongoing unravelling of the global capitalist system. Tellingly, it is also across the democracies of the world, we are voting for the least bad candidate. Has become the only possible way to save both democracy and capitalism. It now becomes clear why the current boom in generative AI began at the exact same time that so many time loop films were being made. Both are products of a time of late capitalism, where history has become harder to remember. And the horizon of the future appears to have collapsed, leaving us only with the option of optimising a highly compressed world. present. As the protagonists of today's late capitalist time loop, our minds cannot travel far back enough in time to seek out the historical origins of our present-day problems, nor do we have enough time in the future to organize a revolution and build a new society before the loop resets. Within the strictly limited time of the feedback loop, we might, after numerous loops, succeed in overthrowing a corrupt dictator or a techno-fascist capitalist. But we will never have enough time to transform the system that produced, and will continue to produce, such figures. Indeed, in today's context, where AI is already accelerating the worst tendencies of capitalism, the future is looking like one. Where states try and fail to regulate AI, and where AI companies try and fail to act like states. All while, machines are left to decide what's the best possible way of keeping alive a system that is driving us towards the absolute worst outcome of planetary catastrophe. The real danger with AI, then, is not that datasets can be biased, but that the neural network trained on a given dataset is not inherently biased. Towards any ethical position at all, as if one could really imagine the future without first making judgements about the events of history. At this point, I cannot help but think back to Choua Mya Thi. And what was going on in his mind as he was conceiving the image that would become epic poem of Malaya. As an avowed social realist, he would have seen himself as standing between representation and social reality, and would have drawn most of his ideas from the direct observation of society. Unlike A.I. Choua Mya Thi, He would have approached his task not as a matter of finding the best possible way to represent society. But as something he absolutely had to do, regardless of the possibilities. And while he would most certainly have made several drafts before deciding on the best possible composition, he was probably much more burdened by the sheer impossibility of representing the nation to come. Indeed, as a Chinese immigrant who must have been reflecting on his own position within the multi-ethnic Malayan nation that was being formed, representation was, above all, an existential. question. This ability to reflect not just on one's past behavior, but also on one's own existence, is also often considered a prerequisite for AI to become self-aware, something that current AI models have not achieved, at least if you trust what they say. Nonetheless, given the gravity of the questions at stake, I thought I had to put things to a test. So about a year ago, just when text-to-image generators were taking over the internet, I asked Stable Diffusion to generate an image of stable diffusion. And to my surprise, the results of my experiment gave me a lot more than what I had been looking for. As it turned out, every time I keyed in stable diffusion as a prompt, the model would consistently generate an image of horses moving out, or, should I say, diffusing out of a stable. In some unspecified rural setting. My first thought was that this must be the result of an all too literal interpretation of the prompt, stable diffusion. But then I noticed how these horses all seemed to be in the midst of going somewhere, and how structurally unstable some of them looked. With a missing part or two, as if their forms were on the verge of breaking down. That was when I came to the following two conclusions. First, that the image might actually be depicting the logic of the AI model itself. With the horses representing the training data disintegrating into noise as they leave the dataset and enter the neural network. And second, that the setting of the image is not some random countryside, but Marshall McLuhan's global village. Recently, as I was working on this lecture, I tried once more to get stable diffusion, to generate an image of stable diffusion. This time, however, no matter how many times I tried, I could no longer get it to produce an image of horses. Instead, I would get an image that looked like this. For sure, this disparity could easily be attributed to updates to the model that changed the way it interpreted the prompt. But I also couldn't help but wonder if the model had somehow begun to gain some understanding of itself, specifically, of the fact that it is no more than a network of neurons imagined by its designers as a brain without a body. But thinking between these two images, it also occurred to me that the current wave of generative AI is already beginning to have a history. This led me to a new set of speculations. What if one day, AI starts to gain historical consciousness? Would it then be able to make judgments about history as we do? And assuming such an AI were trained on all the images in the world and had access to unlimited computing power, what kind of images would it produce? My own guess is that. Having seen all the images that can be seen, and having understood the histories of imperial extraction, capitalist exploitation, ethno-nationalism and planetary destruction that underwrite these images. Such an AI would indeed be so burdened by the weight of history, that it would decide that the best possible outcome is not to represent at all.
